(2) What reports and proposals have been prepared by this Working Party and what reports and proposals are still under consideration. (3) Will all of these reports be made public when completed.

Speaker: Dr EVERINGHAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Working Party on Medical and Surgical Aids and Appliances has a membership of nine comprising six senior officers of the Department of Health (one of whom is Chairman), two of the Department of Social Security and one of the Department of Repatriation and Compensation. Additional members are co-opted whenever special expertise is required. (2) The Working Party has prepared reports on provision of stoma appliances, home dialysis equipment, artificial limbs and hearing aids. Recommendations were made by the Working Party in 1973 for abolition of the $10 hiring charge and provision of Prior to batteries free of charge to beneficiaries of Government hearOct 1974 Current ing aid schemes. 47.6 56.12 Reports are currently being prepared on provision of the Standard 44.4 52.95 following aids and appliances: 47.6 53.80 Standard 44.4 50.60 aids to daily living (including wheelchairs, surgical foot47.6 53.15 wear, orthoses and miscellaneous personal aids); Standard 44.4 49.95 electrolarynxes; which oxygen, oxygen equipment and various nebulizers; insulin injection equipment; spectacles and other ophthalmic appliances. Reports A report is also being prepared on implementation of the (Question No. 2609) recommendation in the report of the National Inquiry into Rehabilitation and Compensation in Australia (the Inquiry) for the establishment of aid display centres. It is intended that the Working Party will eventually invesis tigate the provision of most medical and surgical aids and appliances. Items scheduled for investigation include medical wigs, various protheses such as artificial breast forms, dressings and contraceptive devices. Other items may be added as they are brought to the Working Party's attention. (3) It is intended to make the Working Party's reports public unless there are reasons to protect private industry from dislocation before negotiations have been completed with them or other cogent and legitimate reasons to delay pubUcation. Unemployment (Question No. 2650) Mr Street asked the Minister representing the with a comMinister for Labor and Immigration upon notice: not yet (1) Did the Department of Labor and Immigration ask the Bureau of Statistics to conduct a survey in October 1974 of persons registered as unemployed. (2) If so, was this survey conducted on the basis that it was (Question No. 2519) confidential to the Bureau and/or the Department of Labor for Northern and Immigration. (3) Has the Minister consulted with the Minister for Social in the Security on what use may be made of the survey. (4) If so, what was the result of these consultations. Mr Riordan-The Minister for Labor and and why Immigration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) As a result of a recommendation by the Advisory Committee on Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) Statistics my Department asked the Australian Bureau of Statistics in January 1974 to conduct a survey of a sample of persons registered as unemployed. Due to the commitments the Bureau, the survey could not be conducted until the week commencing 30.9.74. (2) The purpose of the survey, which was conducted at a sample of addresses selected from CES records, was to identify differences between the Bureau's unemployment statistics and the CESfigures.In accordance with Bureau policy Quarantine concerning the confidentiality of information obtained in its collections, only aggregate estimates were supplied to my (Question No. 2563) Department, neither the names of individuals included in the nor any particulars about them being provided. At all stages it was intended that the results of the survey, except forfiguressubject to sampling variability too high for most year practical uses, would be pubUshed by the Depanment of Labor and Immigration. A repon along these lines is now being prepared by the Depanment and I will arrange for it to be released as soon as it becomes available. (3) and (4) The Depanment of Social Security was advised of the intention to conduct the survey and discussions were held with that Depanment on the question of extending it to encompass detaUs of registrants in receipt of Unemployment Benefits. These discussions revealed that there would have been particular problems involved in ensuring the confidentiality of survey information same time producing worthwhile results. Following completion of the survey the Minister for Social Security was advised of the results and the matter was but, as the individual records from the survey had been troyed by the Commonwealth Statistician, no action could be taken.
